title: 7 Days in the Riviera Maya with Kids
subtitle: The Perfect Family Beach Vacation in Mexico
meta_title: Family-Friendly Riviera Maya Itinerary - 7 Days with Kids in Mexico
meta_description: Plan the perfect family vacation to Mexico's Riviera Maya. 7 days of kid-friendly beaches, eco-parks, Mayan ruins, cenotes, and all-inclusive resort fun. Complete guide for traveling with children.
hero_alt: Family enjoying beach vacation in Mexico's Riviera Maya
introduction: The Riviera Maya is Mexico's premier family destination—and for good reason. Crystal-clear Caribbean waters, kid-friendly eco-parks, accessible Mayan ruins, magical cenotes, and world-class all-inclusive resorts create the perfect mix of adventure, education, and relaxation. This 7-day itinerary balances activities with downtime, keeping both kids and parents happy.
best_time: December to April for best weather; July-August for summer vacation (busier, hotter)
highlights: Play at Xcaret or Xel-Há eco-parks

days.title: Arrive & Resort Fun
days.description: Fly into Cancún International Airport (CUN) and transfer to your family-friendly resort (45-90 minutes depending on location). Let kids decompress from travel with pool time, beach exploration, and resort activities. Most all-inclusives have kids' clubs, splash parks, and evening entertainment. Take it easy—you've earned it!
tips: Book airport transfer in advance—private is worth it with kids and car seats
Request early check-in if arriving in morning
Let kids adjust before big activities—jet lag is real

days.title: Xcaret Eco-Park Adventure
days.description: Full day at Xcaret, the ultimate family eco-park. Snorkel in underground rivers, swim with dolphins (optional), explore a butterfly pavilion, see jaguars and monkeys, watch traditional performances, and end with the spectacular Mexico Espectacular night show featuring 300 performers. It's exhausting in the best way.
tips: Book Xcaret Plus package (includes food/drinks and lockers)
Bring water shoes for river activities
Stay for the night show—it's spectacular and kids love it
Arrive early to beat crowds

days.title: Cenote Swimming & Beach Day
days.description: Morning adventure to a family-friendly cenote—natural limestone sinkholes filled with crystal-clear water. Cenote Azul near Playa del Carmen is perfect for families with shallow areas and easy access. Afternoon back at the resort for beach time, pool play, and kids' club activities. Let the kids lead the pace.
activities: Morning cenote visit (Cenote Azul or Jardín del Eden)
tips: Cenote Azul has a restaurant on-site
Bring reef-safe sunscreen (required at cenotes)
Life jackets available for young swimmers
Go early before tour groups arrive

days.title: Tulum Ruins & Beach
days.description: Visit the iconic Tulum ruins—the only Mayan city built on the coast. The clifftop setting is stunning and the site is compact enough for kids (1-2 hours). Descend to the beach below the ruins for swimming in turquoise water with ancient temples above. Lunch in Tulum town before returning to the resort.
activities: Optional: Cenote swim on way back
tips: Arrive at 8am opening to avoid heat and crowds
Hire a guide to make ruins come alive for kids ($30-50)
Bring water and snacks—limited inside
The beach stairs are steep—watch little ones

days.title: Xel-Há All-Inclusive Water Park
days.description: Day at Xel-Há, nature's ultimate water park. This all-inclusive eco-park features a massive natural inlet perfect for snorkeling with hundreds of tropical fish. Kids can float down a lazy river, jump off cliffs (age-appropriate heights), explore caves, and eat unlimited tacos. The all-inclusive format means no stress about food/drink costs.
tips: Xel-Há is calmer than Xcaret—better for younger kids
Snorkel gear included—bring prescription masks if needed
Lockers and towels included
Pace yourselves—it's easy to overdo it

days.title: Playa del Carmen & Free Day
days.description: Flexible day based on family energy levels. Option 1: Morning in Playa del Carmen walking Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue), shopping, eating, people-watching. Option 2: Full resort day with spa for parents while kids enjoy kids' club. Option 3: Mix of both. This is your recovery day before heading home.
activities: Optional: Playa del Carmen 5th Avenue walk
tips: Playa del Carmen is 15-30 min from most resorts
5th Avenue is pedestrian-only and kid-friendly
Ice cream stops are mandatory
Pack souvenirs today to avoid airport rush

days.title: Final Beach Time & Departure
days.description: Final morning enjoying the resort. Most resorts offer late checkout or day passes if your flight is evening. Squeeze in one more beach session, a final swim, and lunch before transferring to Cancún airport. Let kids say goodbye to new friends and collect their memories.
activities: Pack and check out (or use late checkout)
tips: Request late checkout in advance
Some resorts offer day passes for after checkout
Allow 2-3 hours for transfer + airport
Check bags for sand—it gets everywhere!

practical_info.getting_there: Fly into Cancún International Airport (CUN). Most US cities have direct flights. Book airport transfers in advance—private transfers with car seats are available. Drive time to Riviera Maya resorts is 45-90 minutes depending on location.
practical_info.getting_around: For this itinerary, book organized tours or private drivers rather than renting a car. Resorts arrange Xcaret/Xel-Há transport. For Tulum, hire a private driver ($80-120 for the day) for flexibility with kids. Taxis and Uber available in Playa del Carmen.
what_to_pack: Water shoes for cenotes and rocks
Familiar comfort items for little ones

faqs.question: What's the best age for kids on this trip?
faqs.answer: This itinerary works great for ages 4-14. Toddlers can enjoy it too, but may miss out on some activities. Teens may want more adventure—consider adding ATV tours or zip-lining for older kids. Babies are welcome but require more logistics (strollers on sand, nap schedules, etc.).

faqs.question: Are Mexican resorts really all-inclusive?
faqs.answer: Yes, most Riviera Maya family resorts are truly all-inclusive: all meals, drinks (including alcohol for adults), snacks, room service, non-motorized water sports, kids' clubs, and entertainment. Spa, excursions, and premium restaurants may cost extra. Read the fine print for your specific resort.

faqs.question: Is it safe to travel to Mexico with kids?
faqs.answer: The Riviera Maya is very safe for families. It's one of Mexico's most visited tourist regions with excellent infrastructure. Stick to tourist areas, use reputable tour operators, and take normal precautions. Crime against tourists is rare. The biggest risks are sunburn, jellyfish stings, and tummy troubles from new foods.

faqs.question: Should we do Xcaret or Xel-Há?
faqs.answer: Both are excellent, but they're different. Xcaret is more varied with cultural shows, wildlife, and activities—better for families wanting variety and older kids. Xel-Há is a giant natural water park focused on snorkeling and swimming—better for water-loving families and younger kids. Many families do both on a week trip.
